maintenanceevent.eventdescription: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday June 22, 2021 at 13:46

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in 4 series: 1. Cayce Family, 1855-2013. 2. Hugh Lynn Cayce, 1907-1982. 3. Edgar Evans Cayce, 1950-2013. 4. Charles Thomas Cayce, 1984-1990.
The Hugh Lynn Cayce series is based upon the arrangement created by Norrene Leary, former secretary to Hugh Lynn Cayce.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Cayce Family of Hopkinsville, Ky., included Edgar Cayce (1877-1945), known as the "sleeping prophet," the "father of holistic medicine," and the most documented psychic of the 20th century; his wife, Gertrude Evans Cayce (1880-1945), who supported her husband's work and served as the conductor for his readings; Edgar Cayce's father, Leslie Burr Cayce (1853-1937); and the children of Edgar and Gertrude, Hugh Lynn (1907-1982), manager of the Association for Research and Enlightenment, established in 1931, and Edgar Evans (1918-2013), electrical engineer and author.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection is primarily composed of paper materials, including correspondence, legal papers, and publications. Other materials include artifacts, certificates, news clippings, photographs, and audio-visual materials. The Hugh Lynn Cayce series comprises the majority of the collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is open for research use. Permission to publish, quote, or reproduce must be obtained from the Edgar Cayce Foundation.

did.physdesc:
metal, textile
This medal was designed by artist Seraphin Vernier at the close of the First World War. It was given to anyone who served in the Argonne and St. Mihiel sectors between July 31, 1914 and November 11, 1918. The front depicts Marianne, the French symbol of victory. The reverse depicts the Porte Chaussee in the French city of Verdun.

metal badge with pin fastener and enamel facing
front: D.V.G. Westmark (LOTHR)
reverse: W. Redo; Saarlautern

did.unittitle: patch [United States Army European Theater of Operations Headquarters Communications]
patch [United States Army honorable separation from service insignia]

did.physdesc: The Eastern Medal, or the Winter Battle in the East Medal was given to any member of the Wehrmacht and Waffen-SS who served in the Eastern front between November 15, 1941 and April 15, 1942. It was also given posthumously to any German service member who died within the Soviet Union.
